appendix.title: Design Patterns Used
appendix.para: This section exists because I need to write down all the design patterns I have used, partly as part of my assignment (as my teachers can have a benefit in understanding the code), partly as a reminder for myself, but also as concrete real-life examples.
Here is a list of (almost) all design patterns used in RapidDataMapper:

listitem.para: The Db_Decorator class which is used by various plugins to decorate columns in the Db_Descriptor.
See Db_Descriptor->addDecorator and Db_Descriptor->removeDecorator for information (the existing plugins provide real-life usage examples).
Db_Plugin_I18n use it to remap the columns and to add translations of column names.
Db_Plugin_Sluggable use it to add the conversion logic.
Db_Descriptor with its Db_Descriptor->newColumn, Db_Descriptor->newPrimaryKey and Db_Descriptor->newRelation.

Db_Descriptor instances use the Flyweight pattern, as they are managed by the Db class with one instance per described object. Db does not either allow two instances describing the same class, but it allows multiple instances of the same class (ie. Db_Decorator or a descendant).

Db_Connection instances also use the Flyweight pattern for the same reasons as Db_Descriptor does it. The only difference is what they do; Db_Connection holds a connection while Db_Descriptor hold mapping data.
Db_Descriptor with its Db_Descriptor->newColumn, Db_Descriptor->newPrimaryKey and Db_Descriptor->newRelation.

Db_Mapper objects which are fetched with Db::getMapper is not strictly a singleton, mainly because there are no hard restrictions upon the number of instances. Instead it is only implied that it is a singleton.
